channel.title: Goldilocks Analogue - Arduino for audio
channel.description:
Not my project but thought you guys might be interested – this guy Phillip Stevens has designed a new Arduino board with onboard ADC, DAC, and headphone amp. It's called [Goldilocks Analogue](https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/feilipu/goldilocks-analogue-classic-arduino-audio-superpow), and it's using the ATmega1284p, which I suspect is slightly underpowered for most DSP applications. At $50 it's more expensive than most arduino boards, but then it is much more capable. He does have a nice little mono-synth running on it in the demo video, and a full-color touch display to control it.
What do you guys think? Any point in using Arduino/ATMega stuff for music, or would you run into limitations too quickly to make it worthwhile?
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/feilipu/goldilocks-analogue-classic-arduino-audio-superpow

item.title: Goldilocks Analogue - Arduino for audio
item.dc:creator: @debterminer Jason Dickson
item.description:
@debterminer wrote:

what would really interest me is if someone made a general purpose 24bit dac board with the ability to input/output bipolar audio and cv's

Read full topic

item.title: Goldilocks Analogue - Arduino for audio
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

An 8bit Atmel microcontroller overclocked to 24.576MHz for audio DSP? 12 bit DAC for audio?

My opinion: a solid plan for disappointment, only a tiny tiny fraction of what Axoloti can do.

Of course my opion is biased

Read full topic
